awd_abstract_narration:
The Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (GRWC) will be held in Minneapolis, MN (2020), Denver, CO (2021) and Ames, IA (2022), building upon successful NSF-funded workshops from 2014 to 2019. Each workshop will involve approximately 45 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in an intense two-week collaborative research experience. Participants will work to solve important problems from across the modern subdisciplines of combinatorics, including algebraic combinatorics, graph theory, enumeration, combinatorial matrix theory and finite geometry. Students will prepare open problems prior to the workshop under the guidance of faculty mentors from institutions around the United States. These problems will be investigated by small groups of participating students, postdocs, and faculty. 

The goal of the collaborations at the heart of the GRWC is to produce high-quality, publishable research on a variety of topics. Another longer-term goal of the workshop is to help student and postdoctoral participants expand their professional research networks. A strong research network is often a crucial part of building a generative and sustainable research program, and establishing these connections at an early career stage can have a long-term positive effect on the quality, impact, and depth of a professional's research portfolio. Participation in the GRWC will allow students to cultivate a large network of peers from the combinatorics community with whom they will be able to interact and collaborate throughout their careers. The GRWC will also offer professional development workshops to help students and postdocs prepare for their future careers in academia, industry and government. For more information about the GRWC, including a detailed description of the workshop format, please see the workshop website at www.combinatoricsworkshop.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award sponsored the 2022 edition of the Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics, held July 24--August 5,2022 at the University of Colorado, Denver.  This meeting saw the participation of 38 graduate students, six postdoctoral scholars, and eleven faculty in an intensive, two-week, collaborative research workshop.  This was the 8th iteration of the workshop, which has been run annually since 2014, save for 2020 when it was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  This meeting, in Denver, was originally scheduled for 2021, but was delayed by a year due to the pandemic.  An online version was held in 2021.  

The primary goals of the workshop are along two thrusts, highlighting the intellectual merit and broader impacts ofthe proposal.  These two thrusts, broadly, are:

  •  To support collaborative research, producing and publishing high-quality research and supporting collaborative research networks.  
  •  To support graduate student and postdoctoral scholar training, through mentorship in the run-up to the workshop, through professional development held through the workshop and through building lasting professional networks.    

To spotlight the intellectual merit, we note that already six papers have been submitted from the 2022 workshop, with more on the way. The papers submited represent a broad swarth of modern combinatorics.  They range from algebraic combinatorics, to discrete geometry, to theoretical computer science.  This is in line with the varied expertise of the participating students and faculty, and highlights the ability of the workshop to connect students (and faculty) of diverse backgrounds within combinatorics.


With regards to broader impacts, we note that the selection of problems itself -- leading to the aforementioned papers -- is a result of mentorship with program faculty.  We also highlight that professional development within the meeting itself included panels on both careers in academia and careers in industry, giving participants valuable information as they work towards their degree and ultimately their career as mathematicians.  In terms of professional networking, we highlight that collaborations and professional contacts forged at the workshops run long after the workshop is over. We run meet-ups (and frequently special sessions) at major meetings such as the AMS annual meeting; and informal interactions between prior participants at conferences is common.  Participants who ultimately work in industry also maintain contact with the program -- in recent years, several prior participants have participated in our industry panel.  


Last Modified: 07/30/2023
Modified by: Paul K Horn
